title: Graph-Valued Regression

author: Xi Chen, Machine Learning Department, School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University

segmentation: So today I will talk about graph value regression.
So we want to study the high dimensional data.
Why there are two popular methods?

One is the multivariate regression where we ask the mean of Y as a function of given X and the other is undirected graphical model where we model the conditional dependency relationship of Y into a graph structure so that if there's no edge contact Jason case notes.
That means YJ&YK conditionally independent given the rest of the variables.
We combine these two ideas together and we propose the graph value regression where we want to estimate AY the graphical structure of Y as a given function of X.
So as many applications in modern scientific data analysis.

For example, X can be the geometric locations of United States, and why can be various climatological factors we can estimate the graph structure of this climatological factors as a given function of X.

So for the simple undirected graphical model, we know that if Y follows a Gaussian distribution and we denote the Omega is the inverse covariance matrix if Omega JK equals equals to 0 if and only if there's no edge between the Jason case.
Of our node.
So which represents we if we want to estimate the graph structure, then we can estimate a sparse inverse covariance matrix, which can be further down by this optimization.
OK, based on this week.
Suppose our go Kart.
It's stands for graph optimized cart where we assume that YG Max is follows a Gaussian distribution where the mean and covariance function X the data are given us Zion Y pairs.
The idea is very simple.
We first partition the space of X using the diuretic decision tree and for each partition we estimate a graph structure based on data falls into this partition using the graphical lasso.
Then for any X in this partition.
We just take the graph structure of Y given X to be the graph estimated in this partition.
So we propose two estimators, one is the penalized empirical risk minimization and the other is held out.
Risk minimization with established statistical property.

The Oracle inequality of the excessive gap which bounds the risk of our estimator and the negative conditional log likelihood, and the best one and also the tree partition consistency, which shows that we can recover.
Underlying tree structure.
The partition structure correctly.
And finally we show a real climatological data analysis where the X, the 100 different locations of US represented by longitude and latitude.
And why are 15 different climatological factors?
The greenhouse gases, temperature, precipitation, and so on and so forth.
And we showed we First partition this 100 locations of US into different partitions.
For each partition we estimated graph structure.
We also plot the graph structure estimated by putting all this data at different locations together.
We found out that for the if you use a simple undirected graphical model, there's no edge counts.

Contacted carbon dioxide, so which is inconsistent with our domain knowledge, where for, for our method there are always some edge connected to the carbon dioxide that greenhouse gases, and also we found that the graph structure among the coast more sparser than the ones in the mainland.
So thank you very much if you are interested in our work, please come to our poster at.
75 Thank you very much.
